To hold the staff in an isolation while moving it in a zig-zag pattern (also known as a Z-plane isolation), you need to maintain the isolation with one hand and use the other hand to create the zig-zag movement. Here's how to do it:

1. Start with a regular staff isolation with one hand. Keep the staff spinning in one direction while moving your hand in a circular motion to keep it isolated in the same plane.
2. Use your other hand to create a zig-zag pattern. You can do this by moving your hand in a back-and-forth motion, crossing over the isolation plane of the spinning staff.
3. Keep your isolated hand and the staff stable while you move the other hand in the zig-zag pattern. It takes some practice to keep both movements smooth and synchronized.
4. Once you get the hang of the basic Z-plane isolation, you can experiment with different patterns and directions for the zig-zag movement. You can also switch hands and do the isolation and zig-zag pattern with your other hand.

Remember to start with slow movements and build up to faster speeds as you get comfortable with the Z-plane isolation. It's also important to keep the staff at a safe distance from your body and practice in a clear, open space.
